title: How did John Lackland lose his lands in France, when France was much weaker than England? - Quora

response.answer_text: France was not “much weaker” than England. You have to bear in mind that these were not nations as we understand them today, but loose collections of provinces whose lords were loyal to a particular king. Fighting between them consisted of assembling troops from each of the provinces. A king had to be a skilled diplomat to get all his lords working together, because if he angered them, they might pull out… even minutes before a battle was due to begin. John’s father, King Henry II of England, was such a diplomat. John decidedly was not. His lords did not trust him. His opponent, King Philip of France, was. He forged a highly effective coalition. Little by little, one region at a time, he drove John out of England’s lands on the Continent.

King John (lets give him the title he held when he lost his continental possessions) lost those possessions because he did not have the support of his nobility. They rebelled against him on a number of occasions and worked with the French, in fact the French Dauphin was occupying London at the time of John’s death and for several years after. Louis was crowned King of England - a fact the English like to think is forgotten.
